2.text: Choose a storyteller to start making up a story

11.text: Story listeners can interrupt with a word at any time

21.text: Storyteller needs to fit that word in their story

37.text: Think of a superpower. For example, going anywhere instantly, travelling in time, reading minds.

52.text: Ask your teen “If you had the superpower to […] how would you use it?

67.text: Encourage them to give their superhero a name and act it out.

80.text: Now let them choose a super power for you

89.text: Make sure you act it out too!

100.text: Ask each other, “What made you happy today?”

108.text: Ask each other, “What was difficult today?”

115.text: Ask each other, “How can we help you?”

123.text: Try to do this together every day, when you are eating together or before bed

451.text: Be gentle with yourself. Just because something didn’t go well today, or you lost your temper, this doesn’t define who you are as a parent. Remind yourself of the things you did well today, even if they may seem small.

589.text: All children, including those living with disabilities, need love, respect and time especially at difficult times.

605.text: Here are 6 simple tips that you can do to support children living with disabilities:

621.text: 1. Keep your child safe and well

628.text: 2. Try to understand what they are feeling

645.text: 5. Make things that you do the same every day to help them feel secure

660.text: 6. Ask for help if you can

667.text: Type "1" to "6" to learn more about each tip. Type "N" to stop this tip.

683.text: Sorry, I don't understand what you mean.

690.note: This is an argument and it may be used to identify a corresponding quick reply

693.note: This is an argument and it may be used to identify a corresponding quick reply

694.note: This is an argument and it may be used to identify a corresponding quick reply

695.note: This is an argument and it may be used to identify a corresponding quick reply

696.note: This is an argument and it may be used to identify a corresponding quick reply

697.note: This is an argument and it may be used to identify a corresponding quick reply

698.note: This is an argument and it may be used to identify a corresponding quick reply

699.text: Step 1. Keep your child safe and well

708.text: • Keep your country's COVID-19 rules, and also help your child to be active - do whatever exercise you can with them inside or outside your home

735.text: • Keep emergency contact numbers somewhere easy to see

744.text: Step 2. Try to understand how they are feeling

753.text: • Your child may be feeling a lot of stress, anxiety, and frustration.

766.text: • Tell them that you love them

772.text: • Praise them for being good and for trying to be good!

784.text: Step 3. Talking and communicating with your child

792.text: • Get down to your child’s level when you speak.

809.text: • Give them time to tell you or show you what they think

822.text: • Tell your child that you understand

829.text: That's okay! You can always type "Help" if you want to learn more about how to support children living with disabilities.

850.text: Here is a link to disability services in your area that may also be helpful: [INSERT LOCAL LINK]

874.text: • Praise them for behaving well, and for trying.

884.text: • Focus on what they can do, not what they can't.

895.text: • Only help children when they need it. It is also good to build independence!

910.text: Step 5. Make daily plans to help them feel secure

920.text: • Having things that are the same each day helps children feel secure and safe.

935.text: • Make a daily plan that includes some things they like to do.

948.text: • Help your child connect to friends and family members through phone, writing cards, or drawing pictures.

965.text: Step 6. Ask for help if you can

973.text: • Share the load with other adult family members.

982.text: •  You are not alone! Keep connected with people who understand your situation.

996.text: • Share your challenges AND your successes.

1003.text: • It is normal to feel stressed, frustrated, and afraid at this time.

1016.text: • Be kind to yourself and take a break when you need to!

1029.text: • Give your child choices: this gives them a sense of control and builds self-esteem.

1044.text: • Use simple language and clear instructions. If words aren't good for them, try gestures and pictures.

1062.text: Do you want to go back and learn more about how to support children living with disabilities?

1092.text: Well done for adding another tool to your Parenting Toolkit! Children living with disabilities need love, respect and time – just like any other child.

1152.text: Sometimes we feel frustrated with our children because we expect them to behave in ways that they are not yet developmentally ready for.

1176.text: Learning about child development means we can have realistic expectations and also to spot any problems with their growth and development.

1197.text: Sorry, I don't understand what you mean.

1220.text: All children develop at different rates. But there are some things that we expect children to be able to do at an age. These are called ‘development’ milestones.

1248.text: That's okay! You can always type "Help" if you want to learn more about child development.

1265.text: Many things affect our children's development. For example, development is helped by eating healthy food, having immunisations, and parents or caregivers who talk to them a lot.

1293.text: If you are concerned that your child might be delayed in their development, here is a link to services in your area that may also be helpful: [INSERT LOCAL LINK]

1323.text: You can also visit UNICEF's website for more helpful information about child development [INSERT LOCAL UNICEF LINK]

1344.text: I want to learn more about child development milestones for

1385.text: • Us to provide food, sleep, cleaning, comfort and safety.

1395.text: • A strong bond with parent/ caregiver.

1402.text: • Lots of play and attention - the most active time of brain development is during the first 1000 days of life!

1427.text: • Become a curious little explorer - watch out for climbing!

1439.text: • Learn through play and trying things out

1447.text: • Want to learn how to do new things (like getting dressed) and make their own decisions.

1464.text: • Want your praise and your approval

1475.text: • More interested in learning in school.

1482.text: • Start to want independence and trust.

1489.text: • Want to spend time with other children and young teenagers.

1500.text: • May be interested in religion or spirituality

1510.text: • 0–6 months: Smile, babble and cry to attract your attention. We should provide care, cuddling and protection.

1528.text: • 6–11 months: Cling to you, especially when feeling insecure or frightened.

1541.text: • 12–23 months: Start to walk, talk and explore things around them!

1556.text: • Start speaking in sentences and  learning new words.

1566.text: • Does not like to lose or take turns, but sharing can be taught.

1580.text: • May express feelings in dramatic ways (like screaming on the floor!). Can start to learn how to manage their feelings.

1605.text: • May answer back to adults to show that they “know”.

1616.text: • Can be very self-conscious and sensitive

1623.text: • Can learn to better manage anger and tolerate frustration.

1649.text: • Feelings get hurt easily and have mood swings

1658.text: • Try to be the boss and are unhappy if they lose.

1692.text: • Find it difficult to separate make-believe from reality. Still express feelings in dramatic ways!

1711.text: • Their friends are important and affect their choices

1720.text: • Need some freedom but also reliable rules that don't change

1731.text: • Need affection, reassurance, self-esteem, encouragement to believe in their abilities

1746.text: • May talk a lot; ask many questions. We should be honest when we reply! Our child may ask again if they don't understand or want to know more

1775.text: • Does not like to lose, share or take turns, but losing and taking turns can be taught.

1797.text: • The teen years are the second most active time of brain development!

1810.text: • Your child is almost an adult, they are able to communicate with you about

1827.text: • They can think about new ideas, develop their own ideals and set their

1859.text: • Starts to want independence and trust.

1866.text: • Wants to spend time with other children.

1878.text: • They are forming their own identity and have a growing sense of their

1893.text: • They may prefer being with peers more than with you

1904.text: • They may show risk-taking behaviours, frequent mood swings, and rebellious

1915.text: attitudes. They can also have exciting new ideas!

1927.text: • May start to ask questions about religion

1935.text: • May answer back to adults to show that they “know”.

1946.text: • Can be very self-conscious and sensitive. May be very active. By now they should be getting better at managing anger and frustration.

1969.text: The most important things that you can do for your teen in this stage are:

1984.text: • Continue providing love, support and guidance and build a strong

1997.text: • Monitor who their friends are, have clear rules to keep them safe

2014.text: • Be patient and accepting of the person they are becoming - even if it is not what you had imagined

2035.text: • Encourage them to begin to take responsibility for the future

2046.text: • Keep supporting them and loving them so that they feel comfortable, secure, and safe

2061.text: Well done for adding another tool to your Parenting Toolkit! Knowing about child development can help you feel less frustrated by them.

2083.text: If you are concerned that your child might be delayed in their development, here is a link to services in your area that may also be helpful: [INSERT LOCAL LINK]

2113.text: You can also visit UNICEF's website for more helpful information about child development [INSERT LOCAL UNICEF LINK]

2130.text: Remember you can always type "Help" if you ever want more parenting tips or support. Chat to you later!
